document.docAuthor: Che, Yanli, Zhang, Yalin & Wang, Yinglun
document.docTitle: Pseudochoutagus curvativus Che, Zhang & Wang, 2011, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: A new genus of the tribe Issini Spinola (Hemiptera: Fulgoroidea: Issidae) from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new genus of the tribe Issini Spinola (Hemiptera: Fulgoroidea: Issidae) from China

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Length, male (including tegmen): 10.4 mm , length of tegmen: 6.9 mm ; female (including tegmen): 11.3 mm , length of tegmen: 7.2 mm .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–7.
Pseudochoutagus curvativus
sp. nov.
, male: 1. holotype, dorsal view; 2. same, head, ventral view; 3. same, lateral view;
Choutagus longicephalus Zhang, Wang and Che
, male: 4. holotype, dorsal view; 5. same, head, ventral view; 6. same, lateral view; 7. tegmen.

FIGURES 8–17.
Pseudochoutagus curvativus
sp. nov. 8. antenna (scape, pedicel and part of flagellum); 9. tegmen; 10. wing; 11. male genitalia, left side; 12. male anal segment, dorsal view; 13. aedeagus, lateral view; 14. apex of aedeagus, ventral view; 15. female genitalia, left side; 16. female anal segment, dorsal view; 17. pregenital sternite, ventral view. Scale bars = 1.0 mm (Figs 9–10), 0.5 mm (Figs 8, 11–17)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material examined. Holotype 3 ( NWAFU ), China , Hainan Prov., Mt. Jianfengling,
20 April 1983
, coll. Gu Maobin.

Paratypes : 13 ( NWAFU ), China , Hainan Prov., Mt. Tongguling,
26 April 2008
, coll. Men Qiulei; 1 Ƥ (SWU), Hainan Prov., Qiongzhong County, Fushan,
31 July 2007
, coll. Wu Xiaofan.

Pseudochoutagus curvativus
sp
. nov . is also closely related to
Mycterodus cuniceps
Melichar, 1906
( Issini ) based on the long vertex. It differs from
Mycterodus cuniceps
in the following: 1 ) vertex 3.3 × longer in midline than width at apex and not wrinkled transversely ( 3 × longer in midline than width at apex and wrinkled transversely in
Mycterodus cuniceps
); 2 ) with hind wing (
Mycterodus cuniceps
lacking hind wing); 3 ) pronotum without central carination (present in
Mycterodus cuniceps
).
Etymology. The specific epithet is derived from Latin “ curvativus ”, referring to the apex of vertex upcurved in lateral view.
